channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Within Cuba’s Revolution, Glimmers of Tolerance for Voices of Dissent
item.description: In recent years, Cubans close to the communist government have begun talking more openly about the economy, the political leadership and the restrictions they resent.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: People were reflected in a window while lining up at a post office to use the Internet in Havana.

item.title: Veteran Seized by North Korea During Tour Is Back Home in United States
item.description: Merrill Newman was released after a month of detention in North Korea after expressing regret for his actions during the Korean War.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Merrill Newman arrived at an airport in Beijing on Saturday after leaving North Korea.

item.title: Obama Says He Can Envision Nuclear Deal With Iran
item.description: President Obama added that there was no guarantee that an accord allowing Iran to enrich nuclear material for power with enough restrictions to assure Israel would emerge during talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: In Afghanistan, Hagel Presses for Pact On Security, but Is Not Meeting Karzai
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was scheduled to meet with Afghan officials — but not with President Hamid Karzai — to see if he could push for a breakthrough in finalizing a bilateral security agreement.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and AZAM AHMED

item.title: DealBook: JPMorgan Tabulated Business Linked to China Hiring
item.description: Confidential documents offer the most detailed account yet of JPMorgan Chase’s “Sons and Daughters” hiring program in China, which has been at the center of a federal bribery investigation.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: An office of JPMorgan Chase in Beijing.

item.title: Ukraine Demonstrators Say They Won’t Relent on Demands for Change
item.description: Many Ukrainians felt deeply betrayed by President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s decision to abandon far-reaching trade and political accords with Europe last month.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Pro-European protesters sleep in City Hall in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, on Saturday. They also blocked the cabinet of ministers’ building.

item.title: Purged North Korean Is Cut From Film
item.description: State-run television deleted Kim Jong-un’s uncle from a propaganda film, possibly confirming rumors that he was recently dismissed from all his posts.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.N.’s Nuclear Inspectors Arrive in Iran
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency’s team landed in Tehran on Saturday and are to inspect a heavy-water production plant on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: South Africans Prepare for Days of Mourning and Commemoration
item.description: South Africans took to the streets into the early hours of Saturday after the death of former President Nelson Mandela, while the government prepared for more formal commemorations.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Africans gathered outside Nelson Mandela’s home in the upscale Johannesburg neighborhood of Houghton on Saturday.

item.title: Biden Peers Into North Korea at Tense Border
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit came just after North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, apparently carried out a purge that stripped his uncle of power.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Hong Kong Reports Second Case of Deadly Bird Flu
item.description: The second confirmed case in the city involved a man who came across the border from mainland China after being hospitalized there.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Decades After the Cultural Revolution, a Rare Letter of Remorse
item.description: The son of a famed Chinese official posted a letter apologizing for his role in the abuse of his teachers during the Cultural Revolution.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Royal Marine Sentenced for Killing an Afghan Insurgent
item.description: The marine, Sgt. Alexander Blackman, and two others were charged after military authorities found footage of the episode on a helmet camera belonging to one of the men.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Civilians Flock to French Troops for Safety
item.description: The rebel alliance seized power in March, but clashes with Christian militias and other fighters loyal to the ousted president, François Bozizé, have continued.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Egyptian Cleric Convicted
item.description: The cleric, Osama Moustafa Hassan Nasr, also known as Abu Omar, has been in Egypt since resurfacing after his abduction and is unlikely to be returned to Italy to serve the sentence.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Jordan Elected to Security Council
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly elected Jordan to the Security Council on Friday to replace Saudi Arabia, which after it won the seat in October rejected it to protest the Council’s failure to end the Syrian and Israeli-Palestinian conflicts.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deadly Factory Fire Bares Racial Tensions in Italy
item.description: A blaze that killed seven at a garment factory, and the subsequent outrage, exposed a complicated, and at times tense, relationship between Italian residents and Chinese migrants.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Disappointment in Successors to Nelson Mandela, a Revered Father of a Nation
item.description: There has been a struggle to fill the shoes of Mr. Mandela and the other leaders of the South African liberation fight.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Per-Anders Pettersson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family outside its home in Mvezo, South Africa, where Mandla Mandela, the eldest grandson of Nelson Mandela, is chief.

item.title: Ahmed Fouad Negm, Dissident Poet of Egypt’s Underclass, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Negm’s fearless and often mocking critiques of power made him a folk hero, but also earned him a total of 18 years in jail.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Ahmed Fouad Negm’s work, which owed debts to earlier Egyptian vernacular poets and to leftist authors, both chronicled the country’s modern history and served as an accompaniment to its struggles.

item.title: Hagel Seeks to Assure Gulf Allies of U.S. Commitment
item.description: The defense secretary said that the Pentagon would not reduce its military deployments to the region or its focus on countering shared security threats.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, opening a week of travels, spoke to service members on a vessel in Manama, Bahrain, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Protests at Home, Ukraine’s Leader Leaves China Without Aid Deal
item.description: Viktor F. Yanukovich is desperate for cash to meet gas bills and debt payments, but his state visit showed how circumspect China has been in the tug-of-war over Ukraine between Russia and the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovich, left, and Chinese President Xi Jinping attend a signing ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Japan’s Parliament Approves a Secrecy Law Amid Protests
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the new law would strengthen national security, but opponents warned it would stifle democracy.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Rising Tension Seen in North Korea and at Sea Border
item.description: South Korea’s intelligence chief said the North had increased weapons near a disputed border, in what analysts said might be an attempt to divert attention from an internal power struggle.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek, the uncle of Kim Jong-un, was said to have been ousted.

item.title: North Korea Says It Has Released Veteran It Held After Visit
item.description: Merrill Newman did top-secret work as an Army intelligence officer during the Korean War. On a return visit to the North this fall, he was accused of war crimes and held, then released.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BARRY BEARAK and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Merrill Newman arriving at the Beijing airport after his release. “I’m very glad to be on my way home,” Mr. Newman said to the Japanese news media. “I feel good, I feel good. I want to go home to see my wife.”

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Mourning for Mandela
item.description: The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela, on a day of tributes to the man who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and then served as its first freely elected president.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
